metadata.title: Low-strain Co-free Li-rich layered cathode with excellent voltage and capacity stability

images of LS-LLO sample. Fig. 3 Charge-discharge profiles and in-situ synchrotron HEXRD characterizations of the LS-LLO sample: (a) Magnified 2D contour plots and selected in-situ HEXRD patterns (the peak of Al belongs to current collector), evolution of (b) lattice parameters and (c) cell volume during charge–discharge cycling. Fig. 4 (a,b) Diffusion coefficients of Li-ions of the LS-LLO and P-LLO samples calculated by GITT. Raman spectra of the LS-LLO and P-LLO samples after (c) 50 cycles and (d) 100 cycles. Fig. 5 The TEM and HRTEM images after 100 cycles: (a–f) the LS-LLO sample and (g–l) the P-LLO sample. Low-strain Co-free Li-rich layered cathode with excellent voltage and capacity stability Zhuo Yao a Yong Chen a Chenyu Liu a Hao Chen a b Shuxing Wu a Dong Luo a ⁎ Zhan Lin a Shanqing Zhang a b a Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Plant Resources Biorefinery, School of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, Guangdong, China Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Plant Resources Biorefinery School of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry Guangdong University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 Guangdong China Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Plant Resources Biorefinery, School of Chemical Engineering and Light Industry, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, Guangdong, China b Centre for Catalysis and Clean Energy, School of Environment and Science, Griffith University, Gold Coast, QLD 4222, Australia Centre for Catalysis and Clean Energy School of Environment and Science Griffith University Gold Coast QLD 4222 Australia Centre for Catalysis and Clean Energy, School of Environment and Science, Griffith University, Gold Coast, QLD 4222, Australia ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A Co-free Li-rich layered cathode with a very small volumetric strain (1.05%) is constructed. It possesses excellent voltage and capacity stability due to the significant suppression of TM migration, interfacial reactions and structural degradation. Owing to the inherent advantages of low cost and high capacity, cobalt (Co)-free lithium (Li)-rich layered oxides have become one of the most promising cathodes for next-generation high-energy lithium-ion batteries. However, these familial cathodes suffer from serious voltage decay due to many reasons, such as oxygen release and transition metal (TM) migration, which are closely related to nanoscale strain evolution. Here, by combining the synergistic effects of surface integration, bulk doping, and concentration gradient, we successfully construct a Co-free Li-rich layered cathode with a very small volumetric strain (1.05%) between 2.0 and 4.8 V, approaching the critical value of zero strain. Various characterizations indicate that the constructed zero-strain cathode can significantly suppress the TM migration, interfacial reactions, and structural degradation including cracks, lattice defects, phase evolution, and nanovoids, leading to improved voltage stability of Co-free Li-rich layered oxides during the prolonged cycles. This work provides a strategy to eliminate the lattice strain of Li-rich layered cathodes and facilitates the up-scaled application of the as-prepared cathode materials. Keywords Lithium-rich cathodes Lithium-ion batteries Cobalt free Zero strain Bulk doping Concentration gradient 1 Introduction Increasing the energy density of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) can significantly alleviate the range anxiety of electric vehicles and contribute to addressing the substantial challenges to resource sustainability [1,2]. One of the critical points for increasing the energy density of LIBs is to develop cathode materials with high capacity and low cost [3–6]. Among these cathode candidates, Li-rich layered oxides (LLOs) have attracted wide attention for next-generation high-energy-density LIBs due to their high capacity and low-cost raw materials (high manganese (Mn) and low nickel (Ni) and cobalt (Co) contents), especially the Co-free one [7–9]. It has been well documented that the extraordinary capacity of the LLOs originates from the cationic/anionic hybrid redox, which provides the compensated extra charge/ion exchange [10,11]. However, the redox of anions (e.g., oxygen) causes severe voltage decay during cycles, which impedes their large-scale practical application [12–14]. Over decades, various mechanisms have been proposed to unravel the origin of the voltage decay in LLOs, including lattice oxygen release, transition metal (TM) migration, reduced TM redox couples, phase transformation, electrolyte decomposition and interfacial reaction [15–20]. Recently, Liu et al. suggested that most of the structural degradations were triggered by the accumulation of lattice strain and demonstrated the significance of strain release during long-term cycling [21,22]. However, the construction of zero-strain LLOs is still a challenge due to their heterogeneous structure of LiTMO2 and Li2MnO3 coherent nanodomains [23–25]. This unique coherent structure determines that the LLOs must undergo two stages: Li-ions de-insert severally from LiTMO2 and Li2MnO3 components during the initial charging process. The delithiation from LiTMO2 causes the increased local electrostatic repulsion with a tendency for lattice expansion. This lattice expansion, however, is partly confined by the inactive Li2MnO3 domain, resulting in severe nanoscale strain with lattice displacement, uneven Li+ (de)intercalation and heterogeneous electrochemical reactions [26–28]. Therefore, the rational establishment of zero-strain LLOs not only helps better understand the degradation mechanisms but also improves the voltage stability [29,30]. In this work, a “three-in-one” strategy, namely a combination of surface integration, bulk doping, and concentration gradient, is proposed to construct low-strain Co-free Li-rich layered cathodes. Various characterizations demonstrate that the as-prepared LLOs with an extremely small volumetric strain (1.05%) between 2.0 and 4.8 V can significantly mitigate the TM migration and interface reactions, which results in a great suppression in cracks, lattice defects, structural degradation, and nanovoids during long-term cycling. As expected, the low-strain constructed sample delivers a low voltage decay rate of 0.97 mV cycle−1 at 0.5 C and excellent long-term capacity stability with a capacity retention ratio as high as 92% after 300 cycles. The discovery in this work will provide new perspectives for a better understanding of the degradation mechanism and inspire more researchers to explore high-energy-density LLOs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of low-strain Co-free Li-rich layered cathode material The precursors (Mn0.75Ni0.25CO3) were synthesized by a hydrothermal method. In a typical preparation process, the analytical reagent Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O, Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O (3:1 in molar ration) and urea were dissolved into 65 mL mixed solution of ethanol and deionized water. Then, the mixture solution was transferred to a sealed Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 24 h. The obtained microspherical precursors were ground uniformly with Li2CO3 (10 mol% excess), NaCl (2.45 g), KCl (4.74 g) and Al2O3, and sintered at 800 °C for 12 h in air. Finally, after washing, filtering and drying at 180 °C for about 12 h, the low-strain Co-free Li-rich layered cathode material (marked as LS-LLO, Li1.191Mn0.588Ni0.171Al0.05O2) was gained. 2.2 Synthesis of the pristine Co-free Li-rich layered cathode material As a comparison, the pristine Co-free Li-rich layered cathode material was prepared using a molten-salt-assisted co-precipitation method. In a typical synthesis process, microspherical carbonate precursors (Mn0.75Ni0.25)CO3 were prepared via a carbonate co-precipitation method by CSTR with a pH of 8. Then, the carbonate precursors were further mixed with an appropriate amount of Li2CO3 (5 mol% excess), NaCl and KCl, and calcined at 800 °C for 12 h in air and cooled to room temperature. Finally, the pristine Co-free Li-rich layered cathode material (marked as P-LLO, Li1.198Mn0.614Ni0.188O2) was gained after washing, filtering, and drying. 2.3 Sample characterization Crystalline structure of samples was identified by a Rigaku MiniFlex600 powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD) with a Cu-K α radiation (λ = 1.54059 Å, 40 kV, 50.0 mA), scanned over a range of 10°–80° at a scan rate of 2° min−1. The morphology, elemental distribution, and surface structure evolution for samples were collected by the high-resolution field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi- SU8220) equipped with the energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometer and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100F). Raman spectra were obtained by dispersive Raman Microscope (Renishaw inVia) using a solid-state 532 nm excitation laser. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements The electrodes were prepared as follows: 80 wt% of the synthesized powders, 10 wt% of acetylene black and 10 wt% of polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) were mixed by using N-methyl pyrrolidinone (NMP) as a solvent and formed a slurry. The slurry coated uniformly onto aluminum foil, and then dried at 120 °C over 8 h in vacuum. The electrode was cut into disks with diameter of 14 mm, and the average mass loading of active material was 2–3 mg. Using lithium metal as the anode and 1 M LiPF6 dissolved in ethylene carbonate (EC), dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC) (volume ratio = 1:1:1) as the electrolyte, the CR-2032-type coin cells were assembled in an Ar-filled glovebox with oxygen and moisture contents < 0.1 ppm. The cells were measured with NEWARE CT-4008 testing system (Shenzhen NEWARE Electronics. Ltd., China) (1 C = 200 mA g−1) under a galvanostatical mode between 2.0 and 4.8 V at a thermotank. 3 Results and discussion XRD patterns (Fig. S1, Supporting information) indicate that P-LLO and LS-LLO samples show similar diffraction peaks, which can be indexed into a hexagonal structure LiTMO2 (TM = Ni and Mn, R-3 m) and a monoclinic phase Li2MnO3 (C/2m). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to analyze the morphology of the LS-LLO and P-LLO samples. As shown in Fig. S2, both the LS-LLO and P-LLO samples exhibit microsphere structures, which are composed of many irregular nanoparticles. However, different average diameters can be observed for the LS-LLO (2–3 μm) and P-LLO (5–10 μm) samples. To further investigate the morphology and structure of LLOs, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was employed as displayed in Fig. 1 . The TEM images in Fig. 1(a, b, e and f) confirm the microspheres and aggregation of nanoparticles in both samples. The crystalline structures of the as-prepared samples were further investigated by high-resolution TEM (HRTEM). As shown in Fig. 1(c, d, g, and h), a set of lattice fringes with an interlayer spacing of 0.47 nm are observed in different regions, which is attributed to (001) facet of Li2MnO3 monoclinic phase or (003) facet of LiTMO2 hexagonal structure [31,32]. As exhibited in the zoomed-in figures (Fig. 1c and d), the LS-LLO sample exhibits some bright dots in the Li slab of the surface area (∼ 2 nm) rather than the bulk region, which does not appear on the surface region of the P-LLO sample, as shown in Fig. 1(g and h). The surface atomic structure of LS-LLO sample was further investigated by HAADF-STEM (Fig. 1i–l). It is obvious that partial surface lattice lithium sites are occupied by heavy atoms to construct surface integrated structure [33], and these heavy atoms may be Al in terms of the line scan profiles (Fig. S3). The surface difference between these two samples suggests that the LS-LLO sample is successfully modified by surface integration and bulk doping, which is further confirmed by the concentration-gradient distribution of Mn, Ni and Al elements (Figs. S4 and S5). Galvanostatical mode was employed to investigate the influence of surface integration and bulk doping on electrochemical performance at a current density of 0.5 C between 2.0 and 4.8 V. Fig. 2 (a and b) show the normalized discharge curves under different cycles. It is obvious that all the normalized curves of the LS-LLO sample almost overlap, while those of the P-LLO sample decrease with cycling. More specifically, an obvious blank area between the 2nd and 100th normalized discharge curves can be observed in Fig. 2(b), suggesting the severe voltage decay of the P-LLO sample [34]. The specific voltage decay rate of the P-LLO sample after 100 cycles is as large as 2.92 mV cycle−1, which is much faster than that of the LS-LLO sample (only 0.97 mV cycle−1). Furthermore, the corresponding dQ/dV curves under different cycles are executed to compare the variational trend of electrochemical reaction for LS-LLO and P-LLO samples. As displayed in Fig. 2(c) and Fig. S6, both two samples have similar redox peak pairs. In detail, the peak below 3.5 V region is attributed to the reduction of Mn4+/3+ in both layered and spinel phases while these at ∼3.7 V region belong to the reduction of Ni4+/2+ [35]. The peak at 4.2–4.5 V in the dQ/dV curves (Fig. 2c) is attributed to the redox of oxygen [36]. With cycling, the oxidation peaks of P-LLO sample move to high voltage, while the reduction peaks show a big shift to low voltage. What is more, the intensity of redox peak pairs for P-LLO sample decreases with cycling. Differently, these redox peak pairs remain almost in their original state for LS-LLO sample during cycling. These suggest that the electronic structure of oxygen in P-LLO sample is significantly changed which results in a decreasing charge compensation of oxygen anionic ions, while that in LS-LLO sample is relatively stable, indicating excellent structure and voltage stability achieved by this “three-in-one” strategy [37]. The cycling stability of the LS-LLO and P-LLO samples is also investigated, as shown in Fig. 2(e) and Fig. S7. The P-LLO sample displays a continuous decline rapidly at the beginning and then gently after 30 cycles, resulting in a relatively low capacity retention of 90.7% after 100 cycles. Differently, the LS-LLO sample delivers a high initial discharge capacity of 234 mA h g−1 and approaches the highest value of 242 mA h g−1 at the 87th cycle. The continuous growth in capacity of the initial few cycles is due to the continuous activation of the Li2MnO3 component. Even after 300 cycles, the LS-LLO sample still maintains a high discharge capacity of 222.2 mA h g−1, corresponding to a high capacity retention ratio of 92%. Table S1 compares the cycling performance with other representative lithium-rich cathodes, which further demonstrates the excellent cycling stability of LS-LLO sample. In addition, the loading mass of LS-LLO electrode was doubled, which still provides a reversible capacity of 236 mA h g−1 with a capacity retention of 95.6% after 100 cycles (Fig. S8). The rate capability of LS-LLO and P-LLO samples was displayed in Fig. 2(d). When the rate further increases to 5 C, the discharge capacity of LS-LLO sample is still as large as 175 mA h g−1, while that of P-LLO is only 130 mA h g−1. This indicates that LS-LLO sample has an excellent rate capability. More exhilaratingly, the voltage decay, which has plagued LLOs for decades, is also significantly suppressed in LS-LLO sample and shows a low rate of 0.97 mV per cycle after 100 cycles, which is far less than that of P-LLO sample (2.92 mV cycle−1). The above results indicate that LS-LLO sample has very outstanding voltage and capacity stability benefiting from its stable layered structure [38]. To reveal the mechanism of structural stability, the dynamic structural evolution was investigated by in-situ synchrotron-based high-energy X-ray diffraction (HEXRD) during the charge and discharge cycling. Fig. S9 and Fig. 3 (a) show the corresponding two-dimensional (2D) contour plots of the structural evolution of the LS-LLO cathode and the magnified observation of two characteristic peaks labeled as (003) and (110). The reversible shift of peak (110) suggests the a axis changes with cycling and possesses a dynamic stability. And the basically immobile peak (003) during the (de)lithiation process indicates a stable c axis [39]. This phenomenon is very different from that of typical LLO cathodes, in which the peak (003) gradually shifts to a lower angle due to the increasing electrostatic repulsion between adjacent oxygen planes caused by the continuous delithiation [40]. Herein, the constant position of the peak (003) confirms that the LS-LLO sample successfully achieves low strain, which is extremely challenging in Li-rich cathodes. For a more specific view, lattice parameters are calculated by fitting the in-situ HEXRD patterns, as displayed in Fig. 3(b and c). There is a very interesting phenomenon that the lattice of the c axis almost maintains constant and that of the a axis also only presents a very slight change during the charge–discharge process, which is the exact opposite of the behavior observed in P-LLO sample (Fig. S10) and typical LLO cathodes. Generally, lattice of typical LLO cathodes expands along the c axis and contracts along a axis during delithiation [41]. This anisotropic lattice parameter change will lead to a large variation in cell volume and especially result in a serious strain [42]. But the cell volume of the LS-LLO cathode only changes by 1.05% after a full charge or discharge. Such a small change in cell volume solidly suggests the LS-LLO sample is close to the zero-strain property [43]. Therefore, the LS-LLO sample is successfully synthesized via a “three-in-one” strategy, which is beneficial to structural stability, such as mitigating TM migration and oxygen release. The kinetic process of the LS-LLO and P-LLO samples was also compared by galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT). As displayed in Fig. 4 (a, b) and Fig. S11, the Li+ diffusion coefficients (D Li +) of the LS-LLO and P-LLO samples in the early charging period almost overlap. This indicates that the two samples possess the same ability to migrate lithium-ions in the beginning charge stage. However, the GITT profile witnesses a rapid increase of D Li + in the P-LLO sample but a slight one in the LS-LLO sample when charging to 4.5 V marked by a dashed ellipse (Fig. 4a). The rapid increase of D Li + in the P-LLO sample can be explained by the weakened covalency of the oxygen (O)-TM bond along c axis while the little improvement in the LS-LLO sample is attributed to the stable c axis and the slight contraction of a axis, as mentioned in the in-situ XRD results. In detail, in typical Li-rich layered cathodes, the anisotropic lattice parameter change results in a significantly expansive c axis and contractive a axis at high state of charge (SOC). It weakens the covalency of the O-TM bond along c axis and facilitates the charge compensation of oxygen and the migration of Li-ions as confirmed by EIS results (Fig. S12) [44]. But it also tends to cause peroxidation, resulting in abundant oxygen vacancies, accelerating the migration of TM ions to lithium sites and deteriorating the surface-interface reaction. Therefore, typical Li-rich layered cathodes usually exhibit large strain during cycling, and suffer from serious structural evolution as well as capacity fading and voltage decay [45]. To this end, despite lower D Li + of the LS-LLO sample in some SOC than that of the P-LLO sample, its low strain may be conducive to the structural stability. The surface structure evolution of the LS-LLO and P-LLO samples after 50 and 100 cycles was investigated by Raman spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 4(c and d), an obvious inflection point occurs in the upper half of the strongest peak in the Raman spectra of both cycled P-LLO samples (labeled by dotted oval), while the inflection point appears dimly at the base of the strongest peak of both cycled LS-LLO samples (after 50 cycles and 100 cycles). After fitting, the peak II at about 605 cm−1 is attributed to A1g mode of M−O stretching vibration of R-3 m space group LiTMO2 structure [46], and the peak I at high wavenumber (> 650 cm−1) belongs to the vibration of spinel-like phase [35]. The appearance of the peak I in the Raman spectrum of the cycled layered cathode suggests that structural evolution from layered to spinel-like phase takes place on the surface. And the area ratio of the peak I to II is related to the degree of structural evolution. Considering that the Raman spectra of LS-LLO and P-LLO samples without cycling are very similar (Fig. S13), the large value means a serious TM migration and interface reaction or electrolyte corrosion [47]. For the electrodes after 50 cycles, the value of the cycled LS-LLO sample is 20.5%, while that of the cycled P-LLO sample is as large as 50%. After 100 cycles, the area ratio of the peak I to II for the cycled LS-LLO sample has barely changed, while that for the cycled P-LLO sample increases to 84.9%. The above results demonstrate that the TM migration and interface reaction in the LS-LLO sample have been obviously suppressed, which is attributed to the significant enhancement in structural stability due to the peculiarity of low strain. The structural evolution and electrolyte corrosion during cycling were further investigated by TEM. Fig. 5 compares the morphologies and lattice structures of the LS-LLO and P-LLO samples after 100 cycles. As shown in Fig. 5(a, b, g, and h), compared with the rough, loose and spongiosa morphology of the cycled P-LLO sample with abundant cracks, the cycled LS-LLO sample can maintain a smooth and dense surface. These phenomena indicate that the P-LLO sample suffers from serious electrolyte corrosion, leading to severe structural evolution of cathode materials, such as TM migration, oxygen release and nano-voids etc. [48]. Furthermore, high resolution TEM (HRTEM) was employed to observe the lattice distortion of the cycled samples. As displayed in Fig. 5(c–f), clear lattice fringes are observed in the cycled LS-LLO sample. Compared with obvious distortions in the P-LLO samples (Fig. 5k and l), the LS-LLO sample exhibits clear lattice fringes with an interplanar spacing of 0.47 nm (Fig. 5c and f), corresponding to the (003) facet of LLOs [49]. All these results demonstrate that the LS-LLO sample still possesses high crystallinity after prolonged cycles. On the contrary, serious distortions and many nano voids (marked by red circles) are found in the cycled P-LLO sample (Fig. 5i–l). In addition, the fast Fourier transform (FFT) image (Fig. S14) clearly shows that some of the layered structure has transformed to spinel phase in the cycled P-LLO sample [50]. What is more, XRD pattern (Fig. S15) of cycled LS-LLO sample basically stays the same except for the superlattice peaks of 20° to 25°, while that of cycled P-LLO sample appears some new peaks of spinel phase. And dQ/dV curves (Fig. 2c) indicate that the charge compensation of oxygen in P-LLO sample decreases with cycling, which suggests an inferior oxygen reversibility. These prove that Low-strain structure improves the oxygen reversibility of LS-LLO sample and obviously retard TM migration and electrolyte corrosion during cycling. The difference in structural stability and electrolyte corrosion resistance of the P-LLO and LS-LLO samples is highly associated with the strain during cycles. In typical Li-rich layered cathodes, lattice expansion will lead to tensile strain at nanoscale, which can reduce the energy barriers to remove lattice oxygen, accelerate the decomposition of Li2MnO3 domains and trigger oxygen release [22]. However, the low-strain LS-LLO sample exhibits small volume change, leading to an ultra-stable lattice structure [51]. Therefore, the low-strain structure of LLOs can effectively resist chemo-mechanical cracks, lattice defects, structural evolution and nano voids during long-term cycling. 4 Conclusions In this work, a “three-in-one” strategy, namely a combination of surface integration, bulk doping and concentration gradient, is developed to construct low-strain Co-free Li-rich layered cathode with excellent voltage and capacity stability. The surface rock-salt integrated layer can isolate the direct contact between the active material and the electrolyte and inhibit the interfacial reaction. And the bulk doping acts as a pillar to stabilize the crystal structure. The concentration-gradient can improve the surface stability and cycling performance. Their synergistic effect significantly decreases the strain, and improves the corrosion resistance of electrolyte and structural stability of LLO cathode. This low-strain LLO delivers a low voltage decay rate of 0.97 mV cycle−1 at 0.5 C and possesses an excellent long-term capacity stability with a capacity retention ratio as high as 92% after 300 cycles. In-situ synchrotron HEXRD indicates that the constructed LLO sample exhibits an ultra-stable lattice structure. Impressively, the volumetric strain between 2.0 and 4.8 V is as small as 1.05% which is very close to the critical value (1%) of zero strain, thereby significantly mitigating TM migration and interface reaction, resulting in a great suppression in cracks, lattice defects, structural evolution, and nano voids during long-term cycling. This “three-in-one” strategy demonstrates the feasibility of low-strain structure for high-capacity Li-rich layered cathode materials, which can significantly improve structural and interfacial stability of LLOs and address the critical issues of voltage decay. We expect this strategy can promote the large-scale commercialization of Li-rich cathode materials and greatly boost the energy–density of LIBs in the near future. coredata.dc:description: Owing to the inherent advantages of low cost and high capacity, cobalt (Co)-free lithium (Li)-rich layered oxides have become one of the most promising cathodes for next-generation high-energy lithium-ion batteries. However, these familial cathodes suffer from serious voltage decay due to many reasons, such as oxygen release and transition metal (TM) migration, which are closely related to nanoscale strain evolution. Here, by combining the synergistic effects of surface integration, bulk doping, and concentration gradient, we successfully construct a Co-free Li-rich layered cathode with a very small volumetric strain (1.05%) between 2.0 and 4.8 V, approaching the critical value of zero strain. Various characterizations indicate that the constructed zero-strain cathode can significantly suppress the TM migration, interfacial reactions, and structural degradation including cracks, lattice defects, phase evolution, and nanovoids, leading to improved voltage stability of Co-free Li-rich layered oxides during the prolonged cycles. This work provides a strategy to eliminate the lattice strain of Li-rich layered cathodes and facilitates the up-scaled application of the as-prepared cathode materials.
coredata.prism:publisher: Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by ELSEVIER B.V. and Science Press.
coredata.dc:title: Low-strain Co-free Li-rich layered cathode with excellent voltage and capacity stability
